name: matcher
comment:
Support for specifying test expectations, such as for unit tests.

The matcher library provides a third-generation assertion mechanism, drawing inspiration from Hamcrest.

For more information, see Unit Testing with Dart.

isNonNegative.name: isNonNegative
isNonNegative.comment: A matcher which matches if the match argument is zero or positive.

isNegative.name: isNegative
isNegative.comment: A matcher which matches if the match argument is negative.

isNonPositive.name: isNonPositive
isNonPositive.comment: A matcher which matches if the match argument is zero or negative.

isPositive.name: isPositive
isPositive.comment: A matcher which matches if the match argument is positive.

isNonZero.name: isNonZero
isNonZero.comment: A matcher which matches if the match argument is non-zero.

isZero.name: isZero
isZero.comment: A matcher which matches if the match argument is zero.

completes.name: completes
completes.comment:
Matches a dart-async.Future that completes successfully with a value. Note that this creates an asynchronous expectation. The call to expect() that includes this will return immediately and execution will continue. Later, when the future completes, the actual expectation will run.

To test that a Future completes with an exception, you can use matcher/matcher.throws and matcher/matcher.throwsA.

wrapAsync.name: wrapAsync
wrapAsync.comment: Some matchers, like those for Futures and exception testing, can fail in asynchronous sections, and throw exceptions. A user of this library will typically want to catch and handle such exceptions. The matcher/matcher.wrapAsync property is a function that can wrap callbacks used by these Matchers so that they can be used safely. For example, the unittest library will set this to be expectAsync. By default this is an identity function.

throwsCyclicInitializationError.name: throwsCyclicInitializationError
throwsCyclicInitializationError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw CyclicInitializationError.

throwsAbstractClassInstantiationError.name: throwsAbstractClassInstantiationError
throwsAbstractClassInstantiationError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw AbstractClassInstantiationError.

throwsConcurrentModificationError.name: throwsConcurrentModificationError
throwsConcurrentModificationError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw ConcurrentModificationError.

throwsNullThrownError.name: throwsNullThrownError
throwsNullThrownError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw NullThrownError.

throwsFallThroughError.name: throwsFallThroughError
throwsFallThroughError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw FallThroughError.

throwsStateError.name: throwsStateError
throwsStateError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw StateError.

throwsUnsupportedError.name: throwsUnsupportedError
throwsUnsupportedError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw UnsupportedError.

throwsUnimplementedError.name: throwsUnimplementedError
throwsUnimplementedError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw Exception.

throwsNoSuchMethodError.name: throwsNoSuchMethodError
throwsNoSuchMethodError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw NoSuchMethodError.

throwsRangeError.name: throwsRangeError
throwsRangeError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw RangeError.

throwsArgumentError.name: throwsArgumentError
throwsArgumentError.comment: A matcher for functions that throw ArgumentError.

throwsException.name: throwsException
throwsException.comment: A matcher for functions that throw Exception.

throwsFormatException.name: throwsFormatException
throwsFormatException.comment: A matcher for functions that throw FormatException.

returnsNormally.name: returnsNormally
returnsNormally.comment: A matcher that matches a function call against no exception. The function will be called once. Any exceptions will be silently swallowed. The value passed to expect() should be a reference to the function. Note that the function cannot take arguments; to handle this a wrapper will have to be created.

throws.name: throws
throws.comment:
This can be used to match two kinds of objects:

  • A dart-core.Function that throws an exception when called. The function cannot take any arguments. If you want to test that a function expecting arguments throws, wrap it in another zero-argument function that calls the one you want to test.

  • A dart-async.Future that completes with an exception. Note that this creates an asynchronous expectation. The call to expect() that includes this will return immediately and execution will continue. Later, when the future completes, the actual expectation will run.

isFalse.name: isFalse
isFalse.comment: A matcher that matches anything except the Boolean value true.

isTrue.name: isTrue
isTrue.comment: A matcher that matches the Boolean value true.

isNotNull.name: isNotNull
isNotNull.comment: A matcher that matches any non-null value.

isNull.name: isNull
isNull.comment: A matcher that matches any null value.

isEmpty.name: isEmpty
isEmpty.comment: Returns a matcher that matches empty strings, maps or iterables (including collections).

matches.name: matches
matches.comment: Returns a matcher that matches if the match argument is a string and matches the regular expression given by matcher/matcher.matches.re. matcher/matcher.matches.re can be a RegExp instance or a string; in the latter case it will be used to create a RegExp instance.

stringContainsInOrder.name: stringContainsInOrder
stringContainsInOrder.comment:
Returns a matcher that matches if the match argument is a string and contains a given list of matcher/matcher.stringContainsInOrder.substrings in relative order.

For example, stringContainsInOrder(["a", "e", "i", "o", "u"]) will match "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz".

endsWith.name: endsWith
endsWith.comment: Returns a matcher that matches if the match argument is a string and ends with matcher/matcher.endsWith.suffixString.

startsWith.name: startsWith
startsWith.comment: Returns a matcher that matches if the match argument is a string and starts with matcher/matcher.startsWith.prefixString.

collapseWhitespace.name: collapseWhitespace
collapseWhitespace.comment: Utility function to collapse whitespace runs to single spaces and strip leading/trailing whitespace.

equalsIgnoringWhitespace.name: equalsIgnoringWhitespace
equalsIgnoringWhitespace.comment:
Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is a string and is equal to value when compared with all runs of whitespace collapsed to single spaces and leading and trailing whitespace removed.

For example, equalsIgnoringCase("hello world") will match "hello world", " hello world" and "hello world ".

equalsIgnoringCase.name: equalsIgnoringCase
equalsIgnoringCase.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is a string and is equal to matcher/matcher.equalsIgnoringCase.value when compared case-insensitively.

anyOf.name: anyOf
anyOf.comment:
Matches if any of the given matchers evaluate to true. The arguments can be a set of matchers as separate parameters (up to 7), or a List of matchers.

The matchers are evaluated from left to right using short-circuit evaluation, so evaluation stops as soon as a matcher returns true.

Any argument that is not a matcher is implicitly wrapped in a Matcher to check for equality.

allOf.name: allOf
allOf.comment: This returns a matcher that matches if all of the matchers passed as arguments (up to 7) match. Instead of passing the matchers separately they can be passed as a single List argument. Any argument that is not a matcher is implicitly wrapped in a Matcher to check for equality.

isNot.name: isNot
isNot.comment: This returns a matcher that inverts matcher/matcher.isNot.matcher to its logical negation.

inClosedOpenRange.name: inClosedOpenRange
inClosedOpenRange.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is greater than or equal to a matcher/matcher.inClosedOpenRange.low and less than matcher/matcher.inClosedOpenRange.high.

inOpenClosedRange.name: inOpenClosedRange
inOpenClosedRange.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is greater than matcher/matcher.inOpenClosedRange.low and less than or equal to matcher/matcher.inOpenClosedRange.high.

inExclusiveRange.name: inExclusiveRange
inExclusiveRange.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is greater than matcher/matcher.inExclusiveRange.low and less than matcher/matcher.inExclusiveRange.high.

inInclusiveRange.name: inInclusiveRange
inInclusiveRange.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is greater than or equal to matcher/matcher.inInclusiveRange.low and less than or equal to matcher/matcher.inInclusiveRange.high.

closeTo.name: closeTo
closeTo.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is within matcher/matcher.closeTo.delta of some matcher/matcher.closeTo.value; i.e. if the match argument is greater than than or equal matcher/matcher.closeTo.value-matcher/matcher.closeTo.delta and less than or equal to matcher/matcher.closeTo.value+matcher/matcher.closeTo.delta.

lessThanOrEqualTo.name: lessThanOrEqualTo
lessThanOrEqualTo.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is less than or equal to the given matcher/matcher.lessThanOrEqualTo.value.

lessThan.name: lessThan
lessThan.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is less than the given matcher/matcher.lessThan.value.

greaterThanOrEqualTo.name: greaterThanOrEqualTo
greaterThanOrEqualTo.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is greater than or equal to the given matcher/matcher.greaterThanOrEqualTo.value.

greaterThan.name: greaterThan
greaterThan.comment: Returns a matcher which matches if the match argument is greater than the given matcher/matcher.greaterThan.value.

containsPair.name: containsPair
containsPair.comment: Returns a matcher which matches maps containing the key-value pair with matcher/matcher.containsPair.key => matcher/matcher.containsPair.value.

containsValue.name: containsValue
containsValue.comment: Returns a matcher which matches maps containing the given matcher/matcher.containsValue.value.

pairwiseCompare.name: pairwiseCompare
pairwiseCompare.comment: A pairwise matcher for iterable. You can pass an arbitrary matcher/matcher.pairwiseCompare.comparator function that takes an expected and actual argument which will be applied to each pair in order. matcher/matcher.pairwiseCompare.description should be a meaningful name for the comparator.

unorderedMatches.name: unorderedMatches
unorderedMatches.comment:
Returns a matcher which matches dart-core.Iterables whose elements match the matchers in matcher/matcher.unorderedMatches.expected, but not necessarily in the same order.

Note that this is O(n^2) and so should only be used on small objects.

unorderedEquals.name: unorderedEquals
unorderedEquals.comment: Returns a matcher which matches dart-core.Iterables that have the same length and the same elements as matcher/matcher.unorderedEquals.expected, but not necessarily in the same order. Note that this is O(n^2) so should only be used on small objects.

orderedEquals.name: orderedEquals
orderedEquals.comment: Returns a matcher which matches dart-core.Iterables that have the same length and the same elements as matcher/matcher.orderedEquals.expected, and in the same order. This is equivalent to equals but does not recurse.

anyElement.name: anyElement
anyElement.comment: Returns a matcher which matches dart-core.Iterables in which at least one element matches the given matcher/matcher.anyElement.matcher.

everyElement.name: everyElement
everyElement.comment: Returns a matcher which matches dart-core.Iterables in which all elements match the given matcher/matcher.everyElement.matcher.

completion.name: completion
completion.comment:
Matches a matcher/dart-async.Future that completes succesfully with a value that matches matcher/matcher.completion.matcher. Note that this creates an asynchronous expectation. The call to expect() that includes this will return immediately and execution will continue. Later, when the future completes, the actual expectation will run.

To test that a Future completes with an exception, you can use matcher/matcher.throws and matcher/matcher.throwsA.

matcher/matcher.completion.id is an optional tag that can be used to identify the completion matcher in error messages.

configureExpectFormatter.name: configureExpectFormatter
configureExpectFormatter.comment: Changes or resets to default the failure message formatter for expect(). matcher/matcher.configureExpectFormatter.formatter is a reference to the new formatter; if this is omitted or null then the failure formatter is reset to the default. The new formatter is returned; this allows custom expect handlers to easily get a reference to the default formatter.

configureExpectFailureHandler.name: configureExpectFailureHandler
configureExpectFailureHandler.comment: Changes or resets to the default the failure handler for expect() matcher/matcher.configureExpectFailureHandler.handler is a reference to the new handler; if this is omitted or null then the failure handler is reset to the default, which throws matcher/matcher.TestFailures on matcher/matcher.expect assertion failures.

wrapMatcher.name: wrapMatcher
wrapMatcher.comment: Takes an argument and returns an equivalent matcher. If the argument is already a matcher this does nothing, else if the argument is a function, it generates a predicate function matcher, else it generates an equals matcher.

expect.name: expect
expect.comment:
This is the main assertion function. It asserts that matcher/matcher.expect.actual matches the matcher/matcher.expect.matcher. matcher/matcher.expect.reason is optional and is typically not supplied, as a reason is generated from the matcher; if matcher/matcher.expect.reason is included it is appended to the reason generated by the matcher.

matcher/matcher.expect.matcher can be a value in which case it will be wrapped in an matcher/matcher.equals matcher.

If the assertion fails, then the default behavior is to throw a matcher/matcher.TestFailure, but this behavior can be changed by calling matcher/matcher.configureExpectFailureHandler and providing an alternative handler that implements the IFailureHandler interface. It is also possible to pass a matcher/matcher.expect.failureHandler to matcher/matcher.expect as a final parameter for fine- grained control.

In some cases extra diagnostic info can be produced on failure (for example, stack traces on mismatched exceptions). To enable these, matcher/matcher.expect.verbose should be specified as true;

predicate.name: predicate
predicate.comment:
Returns a matcher that uses an arbitrary function that returns true or false for the actual value. For example:

expect(v, predicate((x) => ((x % 2) == 0), "is even"))

isIn.name: isIn
isIn.comment: Returns a matcher that matches if the match argument is in the expected value. This is the converse of matcher/matcher.contains.

contains.name: contains
contains.comment: Returns a matcher that matches if the match argument contains the expected value. For dart-core.Strings this means substring matching; for dart-core.Maps it means the map has the key, and for dart-core.Iterables (including dart-core.Iterables) it means the iterable has a matching element. In the case of iterables, matcher/matcher.contains.expected can itself be a matcher.

hasLength.name: hasLength
hasLength.comment: Returns a matcher that matches if an object has a length property that matches matcher/matcher.hasLength.matcher.

throwsA.name: throwsA
throwsA.comment:
This can be used to match two kinds of objects:

  • A dart-core.Function that throws an exception when called. The function cannot take any arguments. If you want to test that a function expecting arguments throws, wrap it in another zero-argument function that calls the one you want to test.

  • A matcher/dart-async.Future that completes with an exception. Note that this creates an asynchronous expectation. The call to expect() that includes this will return immediately and execution will continue. Later, when the future completes, the actual expectation will run.

In both cases, when an exception is thrown, this will test that the exception object matches matcher/matcher.throwsA.matcher. If matcher/matcher.throwsA.matcher is not an instance of matcher/matcher.Matcher, it will implicitly be treated as equals(matcher).

equals.name: equals
equals.comment:
Returns a matcher that matches if the value is structurally equal to matcher/matcher.equals.expected.

If matcher/matcher.equals.expected is a matcher/matcher.Matcher, then it matches using that. Otherwise it tests for equality using == on the expected value.

For dart-core.Iterables and dart-core.Maps, this will recursively match the elements. To handle cyclic structures a recursion depth matcher/matcher.equals.limit can be provided. The default limit is 100.

same.name: same
same.comment: Returns a matches that matches if the value is the same instance as matcher/matcher.same.expected, using dart-core.identical.

class.name: StringDescription
class.preview: The default implementation of IDescription. This should rarely need substitution, although conceivably it is a place where other languages could be supported.

class.name: FailureHandler
class.preview: Failed matches are reported using a default IFailureHandler. The default implementation simply throws matcher/matcher.TestFailures; this can be replaced by some other implementation of IFailureHandler by calling configureExpectHandler.

class.name: Matcher
class.preview: matcher/matcher.expect Matchers must implement/extend the Matcher class. The base Matcher class has a generic implementation of matcher/matcher.Matcher.describeMismatch so this does not need to be provided unless a more clear description is required. The other two methods (matcher/matcher.Matcher.matches and matcher/matcher.Matcher.describe) must always be provided as they are highly matcher-specific.

class.name: Description
class.preview: Matchers build up their error messages by appending to Description objects. This interface is implemented by StringDescription. This interface is unlikely to need other implementations, but could be useful to replace in some cases - e.g. language conversion.

class.name: CustomMatcher
class.preview: A useful utility class for implementing other matchers through inheritance. Derived classes should call the base constructor with a feature name and description, and an instance matcher, and should implement the matcher/matcher.CustomMatcher.featureValueOf abstract method.

class.name: isInstanceOf
class.preview: Returns a matcher that matches if an object is an instance of type (or a subtype).

ErrorFormatter.name: ErrorFormatter
ErrorFormatter.comment: The ErrorFormatter type is used for functions that can be used to build up error reports upon [expect] failures. There is one built-in implementation ([defaultErrorFormatter]) which is used by the default failure handler. If the failure handler is replaced it may be desirable to replace the [stringDescription] error formatter with another.
ErrorFormatter.preview: The ErrorFormatter type is used for functions that can be used to build up error reports upon [expect] failures. There is one built-in implementation ([defaultErrorFormatter]) which is used by the default failure handler. If the failure handler is replaced it may be desirable to replace the [stringDescription] error formatter with another.

error.name: TestFailure
error.preview: The objects thrown by the default failure handler.
